content: Take a cool bath. Your skin may start to look a little pink or inflamed while at the beach or park, but you'll likely see it and feel it to a much greater extent by the time your get home a few hours later. As such, as soon as you feel and see sunburned skin, apply a cool compress or take a cool bath or shower if much of your skin is inflamed. [3] The cool temperature of the water will help combat inflammation and soothe the pain a little. Your skin will also absorb some water, which is important for sunburned skin due to its dehydration. Soak for 15–20 minutes, making sure that the water is cool yet not too cold — adding ice to the bath may feel pretty good, but it can cause your system to go into shock. Immediately post-sunburn, do not use soap or scrub your skin — it can irritate the skin and/or further dry it out. Apply aloe vera. Aloe vera gel is likely the most popular herbal remedy for sunburn and other causes of inflamed skin. Aloe vera has a tremendous ability to soothe sunburn and reduce the pain. Applying aloe vera multiple times per day for the first few days after a sunburn can make a significant impact on your skin and prevent much discomfort. If you have an actual aloe plant in your garden, break off a leaf and apply the thick inner gel / juice directly to sunburned skin. Make sure you test a small area of your skin first, however — aloe allergies are fairly common. Alternatively, buy a bottle of pure aloe gel from a pharmacy. For best effects, place the gel in the refrigerator and apply it after it becomes cool. There is conflicting evidence as to whether aloe speeds up the healing process. In at least one study, it was actually shown to slow healing. Try oatmeal . Oatmeal is another natural remedy for soothing sunburns. It works quickly to reduce inflammation and itchiness. In fact, oat extract has been shown in studies to have anti-inflammatory properties, which is helpful to soothe sunburned skin. [4] As such, make a runny batch of oatmeal, cool it down for an hour or two in the fridge and then apply it directly to sunburned skin and let it dry. Rinse it off with cool water, but do so gently because oatmeal is also a mild exfoliant and you don't want to further irritate the skin. Alternatively, buy some finely ground oatmeal (sold as colloidal oatmeal in drug stores) and mix it in liberally with cool water in the tub before taking a bath. You can make your own finely ground oatmeal by pulverizing a cup of instant or slow-cooking oatmeal in a blender, food processor or coffee grinder until it has a smooth, fine consistency. For smaller sunburned areas, place a handful of dry oatmeal in a square of gauze and soak it in cold water for a few minutes. Then apply the home-made compress to the burn for 20 minutes every couple of hours. Keep the burned skin well moisturized. Sunburned skin lacks the moisture of normal skin, so another way to soothe it and stimulate healing is to keep it well moisturized. After a cool shower or bath, lather generous amounts of moisturizing cream or lotion onto sunburned skin, which will help prevent water from evaporating. Repeat applications frequently throughout the day to make the eventual peeling and flaking less noticeable. Consider natural moisturizers that contain vitamins C and E, MSM, aloe vera, cucumber extract and/or calendula — all help to soothe and help repair damaged skin. [5] If the sunburn is particularly painful, consider applying some hydrocortisone cream. A low-dose (less than 1%) hydrocortisone cream is helpful for quickly reducing pain and swelling. Don't use creams that contain benzocaine or lidocaine — they can cause allergy in some people and make the sunburn worse. Furthermore, don't use butter, petroleum jelly (Vaseline), or other oil-based products on sunburned skin — they can trap the heat in your body, making your sunburn worse. [6] Sunburn pain tends to be worse between six to 48 hours after sun exposure. [7] Keep yourself well hydrated. Another method of keeping your sunburned skin hydrated is to drink lots of fluids. For the duration of your sunburn (at least the initial few days), drink extra water, natural juice and/or uncaffeinated sports drinks so your body and skin can rehydrate and start to repair itself. [8] Start with at least eight 8-oz beverages (preferably purified water) daily. Keep in mind that caffeine is a diuretic and stimulates more urination, so avoid coffee, black tea, soda pop and energy drinks during the initial stages of sunburn. Because sunburn draws fluid to the skin's surface and away from the rest of the body, keep on the lookout symptoms of dehydration : dry mouth, excessive thirst, reduced urination, dark-colored urine, headache, dizziness and/or sleepiness. Small children are especially vulnerable to dehydration (they have a greater surface area of skin compared to their weight), so check with your doctor if they appear ill or are acting strange after getting sunburned. Think about taking over-the-counter NSAIDs. Inflammation and swelling is a significant problem with moderate-to-severe sunburn, so taking over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) soon after noticing the sun damage is another good strategy. NSAIDs reduce the swelling and redness that are characteristic of sunburn. [9] Common NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve) and aspirin, but they tend to be hard on stomachs, so take them with food and limit their use to less than two weeks. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) and other analgesics can help with the pain of sunburn, but they don't impact the inflammation and swelling. Look for creams, lotions or gels that contain NSAIDs or pain relievers — this is a potentially quicker way to get relief from the medication. Keep in mind that aspirin should not be taken by children or teenagers under 18 due to the risk of Reye's Syndrome , a potentially fatal condition. Protect yourself from further sun damage. Prevention is always your first line of defense against a sunburn. There are many things you can do to protect yourself from sunburn, including: wearing broad-spectrum sunscreen of SPF 30 or higher; reapplying sunscreen every two hours; wearing protective clothing made from tightly-woven fabrics, long-sleeved shirts, hats, sunglasses; avoiding extended exposure to the sun during peak hours (usually 10am – 4pm). [10] [11] Sunburn in a very light-skinned person may take less than 15 minutes of midday sun exposure, while a darker skinned person may tolerate the same exposure for hours. [12] Know when to see your doctor. Most cases of sunburn are classified as first degree burns, which can be treated at home with the above advice and staying out of the sun for awhile. However, extreme sun exposure can also cause second and third degree burns, which need medical attention and treatment. [13] Second degree sunburn is characterized by blistered and wet looking skin, redness and damage to the entire epidermis and upper layers of the dermis. [14] Third degree sunburn is characterized by flayed and dry looking skin, dark red or ashen color and destruction of the entire epidermis and most of the dermis. Skin sensation is usually diminished with third degree burns. Second degree sunburns heal within 10–21 days, typically without any scarring. Third degree sunburns often need skin grafts to heal and always leave scarring. [15] Other reasons to see a doctor after a sunburn include symptoms of dehydration (see above) or heat exhaustion (heavy sweating, faintness, fatigue, weak but rapid pulse, low blood pressure and headache). [16] For children, as a general guideline, seek medical attention if a blistering sunburn covers 20% or more of their body (a child's whole back, for example). [17] Get your blisters properly treated. Moderate-to-severe sunburn typically involves skin blistering, which is a natural protective reaction of your body. If you notice blisters form on your sunburned skin, don't pick at them or break any. Blisters contain your natural body fluid (serum) and form a protective layer over the burned skin. [18] Breaking blisters also increases the risk of infection. If you have minimal blistering on accessible body parts (like your forearms, for example) then cover them with dry, absorbent bandages. However, if you have lots of blistering and its on your back or other inaccessible areas, then get your doctor to care for them. Your doctor will likely apply some antibiotic cream and dress the blisters properly with sterile bandages to limit the risk of infection, minimize scarring, and promote healing. Change the bandages one to two times daily (if accessible), but remove them carefully so as to minimize further damage. Also, change the bandage immediately if it gets accidentally wet or dirty. When the blisters do break open, apply an antibiotic ointment to the area and cover loosely with another clean bandage. One or more blistering sunburns in childhood or adolescence doubles the risk of developing melanoma (a form of skin cancer) later in life. [19] Consider silver sulfadiazine cream. If your sunburn is particularly severe and involves blistering and flaying of the skin, then your doctor may recommend and prescribe silver sulfadiazine cream (Thermazene 1%). Silver sulfadiazine is a powerful bactericidal that kills bacteria and other potentially infectious agents on burned skin. [20] It's usually applied once or twice a day, but do not use it on the face as it can cause grayish discoloration on skin. When applying the cream, wear gloves and apply a thick layer, but make sure to remove any dead and flaky skin first. Always keep the silver sulfadiazine cream covered with sterile bandages. Colloidal silver solution, which can be purchased at many health food stores or made at home, is also a powerful antibiotic and much less expensive and problematic than silver sulfadiazine cream. [21] Pour some colloidal silver into a sterile spray bottle and mist it over your burned skin, then let it dry before covering with bandages. If your doctor thinks widespread infection is a strong possibility due to your severe sunburn, he/she might prescribe a short-course of oral antibiotics to be on the safe side. Be aware that some antibiotics can cause photo sensitivity worsening chances of sunburn again — make sure you are staying out of the sun. If your sunburn is severe enough, your doctor may recommend oral steroid therapy (pills) for several days in order to combat the inflammation and pain.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn">How to Get Rid of a Sunburn</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Shari Forschen, NP</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Getting_Rid_of_Sunburn_at_Home_sub" id="">Getting Rid of Sunburn at Home</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Knowing_When_to_See_Your_Doctor_sub" id="">Knowing When to See Your Doctor</a>
<a class="" href="#" id="summary_toc">Article Summary</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Expert Q&A</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=shariforschen%2Cnp#shariforschen%2Cnp">Shari Forschen, NP</a>. Shari Forschen is a Registered Nurse at Sanford Health in North Dakota. She received her Family Nurse Practitioner Master's from the University of North Dakota and has been a nurse since 2003.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">21 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Sunburns are dangerous occurrences, with about 42% of American adults reporting at least one incidence per year.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> It typically develops within a few hours of being exposed to too much ultraviolet (UV) radiation, either from sunshine or artificial sources (sunlamps, tanning beds).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> Sunburn is characterized by red, inflamed skin that's painful and warm to the touch. It may take as long as two weeks for a serious sunburn to fade, and each incidence of sunburn increases your risk of various skin problems, such as wrinkles, dark spots, rashes and skin cancer (melanoma). There are many natural ways to treat and soothe sunburn at home, although medical help may be needed if your skin is really damaged.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Getting_Rid_of_Sunburn_at_Home_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Getting_Rid_of_Sunburn_at_Home">Getting Rid of Sunburn at Home</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_d2980fb8bc" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d2980fb8bc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take a cool bath.</b> Your skin may start to look a little pink or inflamed while at the beach or park, but you'll likely see it and feel it to a much greater extent by the time your get home a few hours later. As such, as soon as you feel and see sunburned skin, apply a cool compress or take a cool bath or shower if much of your skin is inflamed.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup> The cool temperature of the water will help combat inflammation and soothe the pain a little. Your skin will also absorb some water, which is important for sunburned skin due to its dehydration.

<ul>
<li>Soak for 15–20 minutes, making sure that the water is cool yet not too cold — adding ice to the bath may feel pretty good, but it can cause your system to go into shock.</li>
<li>Immediately post-sunburn, do not use soap or scrub your skin — it can irritate the skin and/or further dry it out.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_3658806f98" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3658806f98')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Apply aloe vera.</b> Aloe vera gel is likely the most popular herbal remedy for sunburn and other causes of inflamed skin. Aloe vera has a tremendous ability to soothe sunburn and reduce the pain. Applying aloe vera multiple times per day for the first few days after a sunburn can make a significant impact on your skin and prevent much discomfort.

<ul>
<li>If you have an actual aloe plant in your garden, break off a leaf and apply the thick inner gel / juice directly to sunburned skin. Make sure you test a small area of your skin first, however — aloe allergies are fairly common.</li>
<li>Alternatively, buy a bottle of pure aloe gel from a pharmacy. For best effects, place the gel in the refrigerator and apply it after it becomes cool.</li>
<li>There is conflicting evidence as to whether aloe speeds up the healing process. In at least one study, it was actually shown to slow healing.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_6e521e3b55" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6e521e3b55')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Make-an-Oatmeal-Bath" title="Make an Oatmeal Bath">Try oatmeal</a>.</b> Oatmeal is another natural remedy for soothing sunburns. It works quickly to reduce inflammation and itchiness. In fact, oat extract has been shown in studies to have anti-inflammatory properties, which is helpful to soothe sunburned skin.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup> As such, make a runny batch of oatmeal, cool it down for an hour or two in the fridge and then apply it directly to sunburned skin and let it dry. Rinse it off with cool water, but do so gently because oatmeal is also a mild exfoliant and you don't want to further irritate the skin.

<ul>
<li>Alternatively, buy some finely ground oatmeal (sold as colloidal oatmeal in drug stores) and mix it in liberally with cool water in the tub before taking a bath.</li>
<li>You can make your own finely ground oatmeal by pulverizing a cup of instant or slow-cooking oatmeal in a blender, food processor or coffee grinder until it has a smooth, fine consistency.</li>
<li>For smaller sunburned areas, place a handful of dry oatmeal in a square of gauze and soak it in cold water for a few minutes. Then apply the home-made compress to the burn for 20 minutes every couple of hours.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_bc9943f680" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bc9943f680')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep the burned skin well moisturized.</b> Sunburned skin lacks the moisture of normal skin, so another way to soothe it and stimulate healing is to keep it well moisturized. After a cool shower or bath, lather generous amounts of moisturizing cream or lotion onto sunburned skin, which will help prevent water from evaporating. Repeat applications frequently throughout the day to make the eventual peeling and flaking less noticeable. Consider natural moisturizers that contain vitamins C and E, MSM, aloe vera, cucumber extract and/or calendula — all help to soothe and help repair damaged skin.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If the sunburn is particularly painful, consider applying some hydrocortisone cream. A low-dose (less than 1%) hydrocortisone cream is helpful for quickly reducing pain and swelling.</li>
<li>Don't use creams that contain benzocaine or lidocaine — they can cause allergy in some people and make the sunburn worse.</li>
<li>Furthermore, don't use butter, petroleum jelly (Vaseline), or other oil-based products on sunburned skin — they can trap the heat in your body, making your sunburn worse.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Sunburn pain tends to be worse between six to 48 hours after sun exposure.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_e389aa6cf4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e389aa6cf4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Keep yourself well hydrated.</b> Another method of keeping your sunburned skin hydrated is to drink lots of fluids. For the duration of your sunburn (at least the initial few days), drink extra water, natural juice and/or uncaffeinated sports drinks so your body and skin can rehydrate and start to repair itself.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Start with at least eight 8-oz beverages (preferably purified water) daily. Keep in mind that caffeine is a diuretic and stimulates more urination, so avoid coffee, black tea, soda pop and energy drinks during the initial stages of sunburn.

<ul>
<li>Because sunburn draws fluid to the skin's surface and away from the rest of the body, keep on the lookout symptoms of <a href="/Treat-Dehydration" title="Treat Dehydration">dehydration</a>: dry mouth, excessive thirst, reduced urination, dark-colored urine, headache, dizziness and/or sleepiness.</li>
<li>Small children are especially vulnerable to dehydration (they have a greater surface area of skin compared to their weight), so check with your doctor if they appear ill or are acting strange after getting sunburned.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-6-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-6-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_cf3a18ac46" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_cf3a18ac46')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Think about taking over-the-counter NSAIDs.</b> Inflammation and swelling is a significant problem with moderate-to-severe sunburn, so taking over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) soon after noticing the sun damage is another good strategy. NSAIDs reduce the swelling and redness that are characteristic of sunburn.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup> Common NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve) and aspirin, but they tend to be hard on stomachs, so take them with food and limit their use to less than two weeks. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) and other analgesics can help with the pain of sunburn, but they don't impact the inflammation and swelling.

<ul>
<li>Look for creams, lotions or gels that contain NSAIDs or pain relievers — this is a potentially quicker way to get relief from the medication.</li>
<li>Keep in mind that aspirin should not be taken by children or teenagers under 18 due to the risk of <a href="/Tell-if-You-Have-Reye%27s-Syndrome" title="Tell if You Have Reye's Syndrome">Reye's Syndrome</a>, a potentially fatal condition.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Avoid-Exercise%E2%80%90Related-Acne-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Avoid-Exercise%E2%80%90Related-Acne-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Avoid Exercise‐Related Acne Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Avoid-Exercise%E2%80%90Related-Acne-Step-1.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Avoid-Exercise%E2%80%90Related-Acne-Step-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_259d76aa2d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_259d76aa2d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Avoid Exercise‐Related Acne Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Avoid-Exercise%E2%80%90Related-Acne-Step-1.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Avoid-Exercise%E2%80%90Related-Acne-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Protect yourself from further sun damage.</b> Prevention is always your first line of defense against a sunburn. There are many things you can do to protect yourself from sunburn, including: wearing broad-spectrum sunscreen of SPF 30 or higher; reapplying sunscreen every two hours; wearing protective clothing made from tightly-woven fabrics, long-sleeved shirts, hats, sunglasses; avoiding extended exposure to the sun during peak hours (usually 10am – 4pm).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Sunburn in a very light-skinned person may take less than 15 minutes of midday sun exposure, while a darker skinned person may tolerate the same exposure for hours.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>

<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Knowing_When_to_See_Your_Doctor_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Knowing_When_to_See_Your_Doctor">Knowing When to See Your Doctor</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-7-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-7-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_a70137e08b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a70137e08b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know when to see your doctor.</b> Most cases of sunburn are classified as first degree burns, which can be treated at home with the above advice and staying out of the sun for awhile. However, extreme sun exposure can also cause second and third degree burns, which need medical attention and treatment.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Second degree sunburn is characterized by blistered and wet looking skin, redness and damage to the entire epidermis and upper layers of the dermis.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Third degree sunburn is characterized by flayed and dry looking skin, dark red or ashen color and destruction of the entire epidermis and most of the dermis. Skin sensation is usually diminished with third degree burns.

<ul>
<li>Second degree sunburns heal within 10–21 days, typically without any scarring. Third degree sunburns often need skin grafts to heal and always leave scarring.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Other reasons to see a doctor after a sunburn include symptoms of dehydration (see above) or heat exhaustion (heavy sweating, faintness, fatigue, weak but rapid pulse, low blood pressure and headache).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>For children, as a general guideline, seek medical attention if a blistering sunburn covers 20% or more of their body (a child's whole back, for example).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-8-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-8-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_ce24b3b5bb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ce24b3b5bb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get your blisters properly treated.</b> Moderate-to-severe sunburn typically involves skin blistering, which is a natural protective reaction of your body. If you notice blisters form on your sunburned skin, don't pick at them or break any. Blisters contain your natural body fluid (serum) and form a protective layer over the burned skin.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Breaking blisters also increases the risk of infection. If you have minimal blistering on accessible body parts (like your forearms, for example) then cover them with dry, absorbent bandages. However, if you have lots of blistering and its on your back or other inaccessible areas, then get your doctor to care for them. Your doctor will likely apply some antibiotic cream and dress the blisters properly with sterile bandages to limit the risk of infection, minimize scarring, and promote healing.

<ul>
<li>Change the bandages one to two times daily (if accessible), but remove them carefully so as to minimize further damage. Also, change the bandage immediately if it gets accidentally wet or dirty.</li>
<li>When the blisters do break open, apply an antibiotic ointment to the area and cover loosely with another clean bandage.</li>
<li>One or more blistering sunburns in childhood or adolescence doubles the risk of developing melanoma (a form of skin cancer) later in life.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3445600" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_f5dd0580e4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f5dd0580e4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of a Sunburn Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid3445600-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider silver sulfadiazine cream.</b> If your sunburn is particularly severe and involves blistering and flaying of the skin, then your doctor may recommend and prescribe silver sulfadiazine cream (Thermazene 1%). Silver sulfadiazine is a powerful bactericidal that kills bacteria and other potentially infectious agents on burned skin.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup> It's usually applied once or twice a day, but do not use it on the face as it can cause grayish discoloration on skin. When applying the cream, wear gloves and apply a thick layer, but make sure to remove any dead and flaky skin first. Always keep the silver sulfadiazine cream covered with sterile bandages.

<ul>
<li>Colloidal silver solution, which can be purchased at many health food stores or made at home, is also a powerful antibiotic and much less expensive and problematic than silver sulfadiazine cream.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Pour some colloidal silver into a sterile spray bottle and mist it over your burned skin, then let it dry before covering with bandages.</li>
<li>If your doctor thinks widespread infection is a strong possibility due to your severe sunburn, he/she might prescribe a short-course of oral antibiotics to be on the safe side. Be aware that some antibiotics can cause photo sensitivity worsening chances of sunburn again — make sure you are staying out of the sun.
<ol>
<li>
<ul>
<li>If your sunburn is severe enough, your doctor may recommend oral steroid therapy (pills) for several days in order to combat the inflammation and pain.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="3445600" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">

<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="91627" data-caid="92500" data-cqid="91644" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="488305" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="19">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can coconut oil help to get rid of a sunburn?</div>

</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">Coconut oil can help soothe a sunburn and may also help to heal the skin a bit faster.</div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="87959" data-caid="88832" data-cqid="87976" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="697675" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="13">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How long do I need to stay out of the sun after I get a sunburn?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Naturopathic Doctor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Wait until the sunburn heals completely before going out into the sun again.  Also, you want to make sure that you prevent any more sunburns. If you have many sunburns, your skin will be more damaged and you'll be at a greater risk for skin cancer.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

</div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="91628" data-caid="92501" data-cqid="91645" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="379308" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="13">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I don't have the materials listed in this article. Are there any other ways I can get rid of my sunburn?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Naturopathic Doctor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Using a washcloth soaked in cool water to help with your sunburn.  Try mixing the water with either baking soda or epsom salts, if you have them.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>13</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="87961" data-caid="88834" data-cqid="87978" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="663116" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="10">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My nose was burned in the sun. Blisters have formed, and they are turning yellow. What should I do?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Naturopathic Doctor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">This is a normal reaction to skin damage. Gently wash your face and nose. Make sure you keep applying moisturizer. You can also use aloe vera gel to help your nose heal.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>10</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="88918" data-caid="89791" data-cqid="88935" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="254909" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="10">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have a dark burn on my face, and when I used benzoyl peroxide, it burned my face. What can I do to deal with this?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Avoid unnecessary sun exposure.</li>
<li>Sit under an umbrella when enjoying the outdoors, even when it's cloudy.</li>
<li>Exfoliate the skin after the sunburn heals. Use an over-the-counter alpha hydroxy acid cleanser and a mildly exfoliating pad. The process of exfoliating your skin can stimulate the growth of new skin cells while stripping away dead or dying cells damaged from the burn.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>As soon as you notice that you have a sunburn, soak in a cool bath for 15-20 minutes to ease some of discomfort. Do not use soap or scrub your skin, as this can cause further irritation. After the bath, gently pat your skin dry and apply a thick layer of aloe vera gel or cold oatmeal to the sunburn. Apply generous amounts of moisturizer to the sunburn until it is healed, and take over-the-counter NSAIDs if you need extra pain relief. See your doctor if your skin is blistered, dark red, or ashen-looking. <span id="summary_last_sentence">To learn more from our Medical Review Board co-author, such as how to stay hydrated or moisturize your sunburn, keep reading!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Get Rid of a Sunburn",
    "name": "Get Rid of a Sunburn",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn"
    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/26\/Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\/aid3445600-v4-1200px-Get-Rid-of-a-Sunburn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60

        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",

            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",

    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Shari Forschen, NP"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Getting Rid of Sunburn at Home",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Take a cool bath. Your skin may start to look a little pink or inflamed while at the beach or park, but you'll likely see it and feel it to a much greater extent by the time your get home a few hours later. As such, as soon as you feel and see sunburned skin, apply a cool compress or take a cool bath or shower if much of your skin is inflamed.[3] The cool temperature of the water will help combat inflammation and soothe the pain a little. Your skin will also absorb some water, which is important for sunburned skin due to its dehydration.\n\nSoak for 15\u201320 minutes, making sure that the water is cool yet not too cold \u2014 adding ice to the bath may feel pretty good, but it can cause your system to go into shock.\nImmediately post-sunburn, do not use soap or scrub your skin \u2014 it can irritate the skin and\/or further dry it out."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Apply aloe vera. Aloe vera gel is likely the most popular herbal remedy for sunburn and other causes of inflamed skin. Aloe vera has a tremendous ability to soothe sunburn and reduce the pain. Applying aloe vera multiple times per day for the first few days after a sunburn can make a significant impact on your skin and prevent much discomfort.\n\nIf you have an actual aloe plant in your garden, break off a leaf and apply the thick inner gel \/ juice directly to sunburned skin. Make sure you test a small area of your skin first, however \u2014 aloe allergies are fairly common.\nAlternatively, buy a bottle of pure aloe gel from a pharmacy. For best effects, place the gel in the refrigerator and apply it after it becomes cool.\nThere is conflicting evidence as to whether aloe speeds up the healing process. In at least one study, it was actually shown to slow healing."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try oatmeal. Oatmeal is another natural remedy for soothing sunburns. It works quickly to reduce inflammation and itchiness. In fact, oat extract has been shown in studies to have anti-inflammatory properties, which is helpful to soothe sunburned skin.[4] As such, make a runny batch of oatmeal, cool it down for an hour or two in the fridge and then apply it directly to sunburned skin and let it dry. Rinse it off with cool water, but do so gently because oatmeal is also a mild exfoliant and you don't want to further irritate the skin.\n\nAlternatively, buy some finely ground oatmeal (sold as colloidal oatmeal in drug stores) and mix it in liberally with cool water in the tub before taking a bath.\nYou can make your own finely ground oatmeal by pulverizing a cup of instant or slow-cooking oatmeal in a blender, food processor or coffee grinder until it has a smooth, fine consistency.\nFor smaller sunburned areas, place a handful of dry oatmeal in a square of gauze and soak it in cold water for a few minutes. Then apply the home-made compress to the burn for 20 minutes every couple of hours."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Keep the burned skin well moisturized. Sunburned skin lacks the moisture of normal skin, so another way to soothe it and stimulate healing is to keep it well moisturized. After a cool shower or bath, lather generous amounts of moisturizing cream or lotion onto sunburned skin, which will help prevent water from evaporating. Repeat applications frequently throughout the day to make the eventual peeling and flaking less noticeable. Consider natural moisturizers that contain vitamins C and E, MSM, aloe vera, cucumber extract and\/or calendula \u2014 all help to soothe and help repair damaged skin.[5]\nIf the sunburn is particularly painful, consider applying some hydrocortisone cream. A low-dose (less than 1%) hydrocortisone cream is helpful for quickly reducing pain and swelling.\nDon't use creams that contain benzocaine or lidocaine \u2014 they can cause allergy in some people and make the sunburn worse.\nFurthermore, don't use butter, petroleum jelly (Vaseline), or other oil-based products on sunburned skin \u2014 they can trap the heat in your body, making your sunburn worse.[6]\nSunburn pain tends to be worse between six to 48 hours after sun exposure.[7]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Keep yourself well hydrated. Another method of keeping your sunburned skin hydrated is to drink lots of fluids. For the duration of your sunburn (at least the initial few days), drink extra water, natural juice and\/or uncaffeinated sports drinks so your body and skin can rehydrate and start to repair itself.[8] Start with at least eight 8-oz beverages (preferably purified water) daily. Keep in mind that caffeine is a diuretic and stimulates more urination, so avoid coffee, black tea, soda pop and energy drinks during the initial stages of sunburn.\n\nBecause sunburn draws fluid to the skin's surface and away from the rest of the body, keep on the lookout symptoms of dehydration: dry mouth, excessive thirst, reduced urination, dark-colored urine, headache, dizziness and\/or sleepiness.\nSmall children are especially vulnerable to dehydration (they have a greater surface area of skin compared to their weight), so check with your doctor if they appear ill or are acting strange after getting sunburned."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Think about taking over-the-counter NSAIDs. Inflammation and swelling is a significant problem with moderate-to-severe sunburn, so taking over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) soon after noticing the sun damage is another good strategy. NSAIDs reduce the swelling and redness that are characteristic of sunburn.[9] Common NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve) and aspirin, but they tend to be hard on stomachs, so take them with food and limit their use to less than two weeks. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) and other analgesics can help with the pain of sunburn, but they don't impact the inflammation and swelling.\n\nLook for creams, lotions or gels that contain NSAIDs or pain relievers \u2014 this is a potentially quicker way to get relief from the medication.\nKeep in mind that aspirin should not be taken by children or teenagers under 18 due to the risk of Reye's Syndrome, a potentially fatal condition."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Protect yourself from further sun damage. Prevention is always your first line of defense against a sunburn. There are many things you can do to protect yourself from sunburn, including: wearing broad-spectrum sunscreen of SPF 30 or higher; reapplying sunscreen every two hours; wearing protective clothing made from tightly-woven fabrics, long-sleeved shirts, hats, sunglasses; avoiding extended exposure to the sun during peak hours (usually 10am \u2013 4pm).[10][11]\nSunburn in a very light-skinned person may take less than 15 minutes of midday sun exposure, while a darker skinned person may tolerate the same exposure for hours.[12]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Knowing When to See Your Doctor",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Know when to see your doctor. Most cases of sunburn are classified as first degree burns, which can be treated at home with the above advice and staying out of the sun for awhile. However, extreme sun exposure can also cause second and third degree burns, which need medical attention and treatment.[13] Second degree sunburn is characterized by blistered and wet looking skin, redness and damage to the entire epidermis and upper layers of the dermis.[14] Third degree sunburn is characterized by flayed and dry looking skin, dark red or ashen color and destruction of the entire epidermis and most of the dermis. Skin sensation is usually diminished with third degree burns.\n\nSecond degree sunburns heal within 10\u201321 days, typically without any scarring. Third degree sunburns often need skin grafts to heal and always leave scarring.[15]\nOther reasons to see a doctor after a sunburn include symptoms of dehydration (see above) or heat exhaustion (heavy sweating, faintness, fatigue, weak but rapid pulse, low blood pressure and headache).[16]\nFor children, as a general guideline, seek medical attention if a blistering sunburn covers 20% or more of their body (a child's whole back, for example).[17]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Get your blisters properly treated. Moderate-to-severe sunburn typically involves skin blistering, which is a natural protective reaction of your body. If you notice blisters form on your sunburned skin, don't pick at them or break any. Blisters contain your natural body fluid (serum) and form a protective layer over the burned skin.[18] Breaking blisters also increases the risk of infection. If you have minimal blistering on accessible body parts (like your forearms, for example) then cover them with dry, absorbent bandages. However, if you have lots of blistering and its on your back or other inaccessible areas, then get your doctor to care for them. Your doctor will likely apply some antibiotic cream and dress the blisters properly with sterile bandages to limit the risk of infection, minimize scarring, and promote healing.\n\nChange the bandages one to two times daily (if accessible), but remove them carefully so as to minimize further damage. Also, change the bandage immediately if it gets accidentally wet or dirty.\nWhen the blisters do break open, apply an antibiotic ointment to the area and cover loosely with another clean bandage.\nOne or more blistering sunburns in childhood or adolescence doubles the risk of developing melanoma (a form of skin cancer) later in life.[19]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider silver sulfadiazine cream. If your sunburn is particularly severe and involves blistering and flaying of the skin, then your doctor may recommend and prescribe silver sulfadiazine cream (Thermazene 1%). Silver sulfadiazine is a powerful bactericidal that kills bacteria and other potentially infectious agents on burned skin.[20] It's usually applied once or twice a day, but do not use it on the face as it can cause grayish discoloration on skin. When applying the cream, wear gloves and apply a thick layer, but make sure to remove any dead and flaky skin first. Always keep the silver sulfadiazine cream covered with sterile bandages.\n\nColloidal silver solution, which can be purchased at many health food stores or made at home, is also a powerful antibiotic and much less expensive and problematic than silver sulfadiazine cream.[21] Pour some colloidal silver into a sterile spray bottle and mist it over your burned skin, then let it dry before covering with bandages.\nIf your doctor thinks widespread infection is a strong possibility due to your severe sunburn, he\/she might prescribe a short-course of oral antibiotics to be on the safe side. Be aware that some antibiotics can cause photo sensitivity worsening chances of sunburn again \u2014 make sure you are staying out of the sun.\n\nIf your sunburn is severe enough, your doctor may recommend oral steroid therapy (pills) for several days in order to combat the inflammation and pain."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],

title: How to Get Rid of a Sunburn
content_html:
Take a cool bath. Your skin may start to look a little pink or inflamed while at the beach or park, but you'll likely see it and feel it to a much greater extent by the time your get home a few hours later. As such, as soon as you feel and see sunburned skin, apply a cool compress or take a cool bath or shower if much of your skin is inflamed.[3] The cool temperature of the water will help combat inflammation and soothe the pain a little. Your skin will also absorb some water, which is important for sunburned skin due to its dehydration.
  • Soak for 15–20 minutes, making sure that the water is cool yet not too cold — adding ice to the bath may feel pretty good, but it can cause your system to go into shock.
  • Immediately post-sunburn, do not use soap or scrub your skin — it can irritate the skin and/or further dry it out.
Apply aloe vera. Aloe vera gel is likely the most popular herbal remedy for sunburn and other causes of inflamed skin. Aloe vera has a tremendous ability to soothe sunburn and reduce the pain. Applying aloe vera multiple times per day for the first few days after a sunburn can make a significant impact on your skin and prevent much discomfort.
  • If you have an actual aloe plant in your garden, break off a leaf and apply the thick inner gel / juice directly to sunburned skin. Make sure you test a small area of your skin first, however — aloe allergies are fairly common.
  • Alternatively, buy a bottle of pure aloe gel from a pharmacy. For best effects, place the gel in the refrigerator and apply it after it becomes cool.
  • There is conflicting evidence as to whether aloe speeds up the healing process. In at least one study, it was actually shown to slow healing.
Try oatmeal. Oatmeal is another natural remedy for soothing sunburns. It works quickly to reduce inflammation and itchiness. In fact, oat extract has been shown in studies to have anti-inflammatory properties, which is helpful to soothe sunburned skin.[4] As such, make a runny batch of oatmeal, cool it down for an hour or two in the fridge and then apply it directly to sunburned skin and let it dry. Rinse it off with cool water, but do so gently because oatmeal is also a mild exfoliant and you don't want to further irritate the skin.
  • Alternatively, buy some finely ground oatmeal (sold as colloidal oatmeal in drug stores) and mix it in liberally with cool water in the tub before taking a bath.
  • You can make your own finely ground oatmeal by pulverizing a cup of instant or slow-cooking oatmeal in a blender, food processor or coffee grinder until it has a smooth, fine consistency.
  • For smaller sunburned areas, place a handful of dry oatmeal in a square of gauze and soak it in cold water for a few minutes. Then apply the home-made compress to the burn for 20 minutes every couple of hours.
Keep the burned skin well moisturized. Sunburned skin lacks the moisture of normal skin, so another way to soothe it and stimulate healing is to keep it well moisturized. After a cool shower or bath, lather generous amounts of moisturizing cream or lotion onto sunburned skin, which will help prevent water from evaporating. Repeat applications frequently throughout the day to make the eventual peeling and flaking less noticeable. Consider natural moisturizers that contain vitamins C and E, MSM, aloe vera, cucumber extract and/or calendula — all help to soothe and help repair damaged skin.[5]
  • If the sunburn is particularly painful, consider applying some hydrocortisone cream. A low-dose (less than 1%) hydrocortisone cream is helpful for quickly reducing pain and swelling.
  • Don't use creams that contain benzocaine or lidocaine — they can cause allergy in some people and make the sunburn worse.
  • Furthermore, don't use butter, petroleum jelly (Vaseline), or other oil-based products on sunburned skin — they can trap the heat in your body, making your sunburn worse.[6]
  • Sunburn pain tends to be worse between six to 48 hours after sun exposure.[7]
Keep yourself well hydrated. Another method of keeping your sunburned skin hydrated is to drink lots of fluids. For the duration of your sunburn (at least the initial few days), drink extra water, natural juice and/or uncaffeinated sports drinks so your body and skin can rehydrate and start to repair itself.[8] Start with at least eight 8-oz beverages (preferably purified water) daily. Keep in mind that caffeine is a diuretic and stimulates more urination, so avoid coffee, black tea, soda pop and energy drinks during the initial stages of sunburn.
  • Because sunburn draws fluid to the skin's surface and away from the rest of the body, keep on the lookout symptoms of dehydration: dry mouth, excessive thirst, reduced urination, dark-colored urine, headache, dizziness and/or sleepiness.
  • Small children are especially vulnerable to dehydration (they have a greater surface area of skin compared to their weight), so check with your doctor if they appear ill or are acting strange after getting sunburned.
Think about taking over-the-counter NSAIDs. Inflammation and swelling is a significant problem with moderate-to-severe sunburn, so taking over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) soon after noticing the sun damage is another good strategy. NSAIDs reduce the swelling and redness that are characteristic of sunburn.[9] Common NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve) and aspirin, but they tend to be hard on stomachs, so take them with food and limit their use to less than two weeks. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) and other analgesics can help with the pain of sunburn, but they don't impact the inflammation and swelling.
  • Look for creams, lotions or gels that contain NSAIDs or pain relievers — this is a potentially quicker way to get relief from the medication.
  • Keep in mind that aspirin should not be taken by children or teenagers under 18 due to the risk of Reye's Syndrome, a potentially fatal condition.
Protect yourself from further sun damage. Prevention is always your first line of defense against a sunburn. There are many things you can do to protect yourself from sunburn, including: wearing broad-spectrum sunscreen of SPF 30 or higher; reapplying sunscreen every two hours; wearing protective clothing made from tightly-woven fabrics, long-sleeved shirts, hats, sunglasses; avoiding extended exposure to the sun during peak hours (usually 10am – 4pm).[10][11]
  • Sunburn in a very light-skinned person may take less than 15 minutes of midday sun exposure, while a darker skinned person may tolerate the same exposure for hours.[12]
Know when to see your doctor. Most cases of sunburn are classified as first degree burns, which can be treated at home with the above advice and staying out of the sun for awhile. However, extreme sun exposure can also cause second and third degree burns, which need medical attention and treatment.[13] Second degree sunburn is characterized by blistered and wet looking skin, redness and damage to the entire epidermis and upper layers of the dermis.[14] Third degree sunburn is characterized by flayed and dry looking skin, dark red or ashen color and destruction of the entire epidermis and most of the dermis. Skin sensation is usually diminished with third degree burns.
  • Second degree sunburns heal within 10–21 days, typically without any scarring. Third degree sunburns often need skin grafts to heal and always leave scarring.[15]
  • Other reasons to see a doctor after a sunburn include symptoms of dehydration (see above) or heat exhaustion (heavy sweating, faintness, fatigue, weak but rapid pulse, low blood pressure and headache).[16]
  • For children, as a general guideline, seek medical attention if a blistering sunburn covers 20% or more of their body (a child's whole back, for example).[17]
Get your blisters properly treated. Moderate-to-severe sunburn typically involves skin blistering, which is a natural protective reaction of your body. If you notice blisters form on your sunburned skin, don't pick at them or break any. Blisters contain your natural body fluid (serum) and form a protective layer over the burned skin.[18] Breaking blisters also increases the risk of infection. If you have minimal blistering on accessible body parts (like your forearms, for example) then cover them with dry, absorbent bandages. However, if you have lots of blistering and its on your back or other inaccessible areas, then get your doctor to care for them. Your doctor will likely apply some antibiotic cream and dress the blisters properly with sterile bandages to limit the risk of infection, minimize scarring, and promote healing.
  • Change the bandages one to two times daily (if accessible), but remove them carefully so as to minimize further damage. Also, change the bandage immediately if it gets accidentally wet or dirty.
  • When the blisters do break open, apply an antibiotic ointment to the area and cover loosely with another clean bandage.
  • One or more blistering sunburns in childhood or adolescence doubles the risk of developing melanoma (a form of skin cancer) later in life.[19]
Consider silver sulfadiazine cream. If your sunburn is particularly severe and involves blistering and flaying of the skin, then your doctor may recommend and prescribe silver sulfadiazine cream (Thermazene 1%). Silver sulfadiazine is a powerful bactericidal that kills bacteria and other potentially infectious agents on burned skin.[20] It's usually applied once or twice a day, but do not use it on the face as it can cause grayish discoloration on skin. When applying the cream, wear gloves and apply a thick layer, but make sure to remove any dead and flaky skin first. Always keep the silver sulfadiazine cream covered with sterile bandages.
  • Colloidal silver solution, which can be purchased at many health food stores or made at home, is also a powerful antibiotic and much less expensive and problematic than silver sulfadiazine cream.[21] Pour some colloidal silver into a sterile spray bottle and mist it over your burned skin, then let it dry before covering with bandages.
  • If your doctor thinks widespread infection is a strong possibility due to your severe sunburn, he/she might prescribe a short-course of oral antibiotics to be on the safe side. Be aware that some antibiotics can cause photo sensitivity worsening chances of sunburn again — make sure you are staying out of the sun.
      • If your sunburn is severe enough, your doctor may recommend oral steroid therapy (pills) for several days in order to combat the inflammation and pain.
